name: JCAlgTest
title: JCAlgTest
author: CRoCS
description:
Automated testing tool for algorithms supported by particular smart card with JavaCard platform.

Contribution with results for YOUR card is wanted! (and highly appreciated :))
usage:
The installation should be simple without any required information. Install this applet on the card you want to test. You can install default (newest version and latest sdk). If the install fails, choose different, older sdk version as the card might not support it.


Run Java application AlgTestJClient. You need to download this application for your pc from GitHub (https://github.com/crocs-muni/JCAlgTest/releases). Once you download the application (AlgTestJClient.jar file inside zip release), and the card is plugged in, open command line (windows ctrl+R and type cmd). Navigate to the folder where you have downloaded the file and run following command: java -jar AlgTestJClient.jar. On Linux you might need to set the smartcardio library, for example use: 'java -Dsun.security.smartcardio.library=/usr/lib64/libpcsclite.so.1 -jar AlgTestJClient.jar'

Choose the target reader for card with uploaded AlgTest applet and let it run. Now new CSV file with values separated by the semicolon is created (AlgTest_ATR.csv).


Please consider to send us (petr@svenda.com) your results in case your card is not yet in the database at https://www.fi.muni.cz/~xsvenda/jcalgtest/




How to navigate in command line: use cd [foldername you want to enter] and dir on windows or ls on linux to display current foler content. Enclose the foldername in " characters if any space is present.

name: JCMemory
title: JCMemory
author: CRoCS
description: Small applet for card memory analysis. Can obtain the amount of free memory space on given cards, which enables us to predict installation failures because of low memory.
usage: The installation should be simple without any required information. This applet is used by JCAppStore natively. You can obtain the free memory space available in 'App' menu item. The check is also performed on an applet installation.

title: Digital signing, OpenPGP and mail security

name: YubicoYkneoOpenPGP
title: YubiKey NEO App: OpenPGP
author: Yubico
description:
This project implement the OpenPGP card functionality used on the YubiKey NEO device that is sold by Yubico.

This project is based on the Java Card OpenPGP Card project made by Joeri de Ruiter. The initial modifications we have made compared to the upstream project are minor, but we reserve the right to make other changes and improvements that are specific to the YubiKey NEO hardware.

License: The upstream project was released under the GPLv2+ and our fork uses the same license. All of our changes are released under the same license. More on the website.

You can have only one applet from OpenPGP Card Applets category installed on your card.
usage:
The installation should be simple without any required information. However, the applet uses advanced functionality and some older cards will not be able to install it. The usage - altough with host application - may be difficult if you are not used to work with command line. (see the turorials in link below). The OpenPGP Card applet is typically used through GnuPG (https://www.gnupg.org/) so we refer to its documentation for the full reference. The default PIN set is `123456' and the default admin PIN is `12345678'. We have tutorials on specific topics in at developers.yubico.com/PGP, for example card editing and key import.

How to change your admin pin step by step:

  1. Download GnuPG (this is used by JCAppStore as well, so you probably have it)
  2. Use command line to launch GnuPG in card edit mode: gpg --card-edit
  3. enter command admin to enable utility tools
  4. enter command passwd to change your admin PIN

For more info about available commands in card edit mode type help. Full tutorials are available at https://www.gnupg.org/documentation/guides.html.

We recommend to search for 'GnuPG [action I want to do]' rather than reading the documentation, for example 'gnupg.org import key to card' yields https://blog.josefsson.org/2014/06/23/offline-gnupg-master-key-and-subkeys-on-yubikey-neo-smartcard/.

name: AnssiSmartPGP
title: Smart PGP
author: ANSSI
description:
SmartPGP is a free and open source implementation of the OpenPGP card 3.4 specification in JavaCard.

Features

The following features are implemented at the applet level, but some of them depend on underlying hardware support and available (non-)volatile memory resources:

  • RSA (>= 2048 bits modulus, 17 bits exponent) and ECC (NIST P-256, NIST P-384, NIST P-521, brainpool p256r1, brainpool p384r1 and brainpool p512r1) for signature, encryption and authentication;
  • On-board key generation and external private key import;
  • PIN codes (user, admin and resetting code) up to 127 characters;
  • Certificate up to 1 kB (DER encoded) for each key;
  • Login, URL, and private DOs up to 256 bytes;
  • Command and response chaining;
  • AES 128/256 bits deciphering primitive;
  • Secure messaging (see below).

You can have only one applet from OpenPGP Card Applets category installed on your card.
usage:
You are required to change two "AFAF" bytes of AID D276000124010304AFAF000000000000 in the advanced install dialog window section. These two bytes should correspond to the OpenPGPCard identifier of your card manufacturer (ask your vendor for this information). If the card manufacturer does not have the ID assigned, you cannot use this applet. These The applet uses advanced functionality and some older cards will not be able to install it.

Default values

The SmartPGP applet is configured with the following default values:

    Admin PIN is 12345678;
  • User PIN is 123456;
  • No PUK (a.k.a. resetting code) is defined;
  • RSA 2048 bits for PGP keys;
  • NIST P-256 for the secure messaging key.

Host applications

There are two host applications available. You can use this applet in GnuPG (similarly as the Yubico OpenPGP applet), or in OpenKeychain.

GnuPG

Supported starting from GnuPG version 2.1.16. The specific secure messaging of the SmartPGP applet is not supported at is not part of the OpenPGP card specification.

How to change your admin pin step by step:

  1. Download GnuPG (this is used by JCAppStore as well, so you probably have it)
  2. Use command line to launch GnuPG in card edit mode: gpg --card-edit
  3. enter command admin to enable utility tools
  4. enter command passwd to change your admin PIN

Upload your private key to the card ( this is destructive action!)
  1. use gpg --list-keys to see which keys you have available
  2. type in gpg --edit-key [key id] where key id is an id for the key you want to move (id select from previous command)
  3. use toggle to switch to the private key part
  4. use keytocard to upload the private key part onto card destructively
  5. follow the GnuPG instructions

That's it! For more info about available commands in card edit mode type help. Full tutorials are available at https://www.gnupg.org/documentation/guides.html.

We recommend to search for 'GnuPG [action I want to do]' rather than reading the documentation, for example 'gnupg.org import key to card' yields https://blog.josefsson.org/2014/06/23/offline-gnupg-master-key-and-subkeys-on-yubikey-neo-smartcard/.

OpenKeychain

Supported starting from OpenKeychain version 4.2. The secure messaging of the SmartPGP applet is fully supported in OpenKeychain. See the section below for more information on the setup process.

name: JavaCardOSFluffyPGP
title: Fluffy PGP Applet
author: JavaCardOS
description: The FluffyPGP Applet implements the OpenGPG Card v 2.0.1 specification without using secure channels or Global Platform for portability.
usage:
No installation parameters are required. You can use this applet in GnuPG (similarly as the Yubico OpenPGP applet)

Default values

The applet is configured with the following default values:

  • Admin PIN is 12345678
  • User PIN is 12345678

GnuPG

How to change your admin pin step by step:

  1. Download GnuPG (this is used by JCAppStore as well, so you probably have it)
  2. Use command line to launch GnuPG in card edit mode: gpg --card-edit
  3. enter command admin to enable utility tools
  4. enter command passwd to change your admin PIN

Upload your private key to the card ( this is destructive action!)
  1. use gpg --list-keys to see which keys you have available
  2. type in gpg --edit-key [key id] where key id is an id for the key you want to move (id select from previous command)
  3. use toggle to switch to the private key part
  4. use keytocard to upload the private key part onto card destructively
  5. follow the GnuPG instructions

That's it! For more info about available commands in card edit mode type help. Full tutorials are available at https://www.gnupg.org/documentation/guides.html.

We recommend to search for 'GnuPG [action I want to do]' rather than reading the documentation, for example 'gnupg.org import key to card' yields https://blog.josefsson.org/2014/06/23/offline-gnupg-master-key-and-subkeys-on-yubikey-neo-smartcard/.

OpenKeychain

Supported starting from OpenKeychain version 4.2. The secure messaging of the SmartPGP applet is fully supported in OpenKeychain. See the section below for more information on the setup process.

name: PChovanecJCOpenPGP
title: JC Open PGP
author: Petr Chovanec
description:
Aim of this project is to create JavaCard applet implementing Functional Specification of the OpenPGP application on ISO Smart Card Operating Systems.

Applet supports:
3x 2048-bit RSA CRT keypair
Key import (using Key Import Utility)
Key generation on card
Most of Data Objects from OpenPGP Card v2.

Because GnuPG doesn't support RSA CRT key import you need to use Key Import Utility (download from official repository). To enable key import follow these steps (WinXP only):
1. Copy WinSCard.dll from your Windows\System32 directory to GnuPG installation
2. Rename WinSCard.dll to original.dll
3. Copy winscard.dll from folder Key Import Utility to GnuPG installation.
usage:
No installation parameters are required. You can use this applet in GnuPG (similarly as the Yubico OpenPGP applet)

Default values

The applet is configured with the following default values:

  • Admin PIN is 12345678
  • User PIN is 12345678

GnuPG

How to change your admin pin step by step:

  1. Download GnuPG (this is used by JCAppStore as well, so you probably have it)
  2. Use command line to launch GnuPG in card edit mode: gpg --card-edit
  3. enter command admin to enable utility tools
  4. enter command passwd to change your admin PIN

Upload your private key to the card ( this is destructive action!)
  1. use gpg --list-keys to see which keys you have available
  2. type in gpg --edit-key [key id] where key id is an id for the key you want to move (id select from previous command)
  3. use toggle to switch to the private key part
  4. use keytocard to upload the private key part onto card destructively
  5. follow the GnuPG instructions

That's it! For more info about available commands in card edit mode type help. Full tutorials are available at https://www.gnupg.org/documentation/guides.html.

We recommend to search for 'GnuPG [action I want to do]' rather than reading the documentation, for example 'gnupg.org import key to card' yields https://blog.josefsson.org/2014/06/23/offline-gnupg-master-key-and-subkeys-on-yubikey-neo-smartcard/.

OpenKeychain

Supported starting from OpenKeychain version 4.2. The secure messaging of the SmartPGP applet is fully supported in OpenKeychain. See the section below for more information on the setup process.

name: VletouxGidsApplet
title: GIDS Applet
author: Vletoux
description:
Generic Identity Device Specification (GIDS) smart card is the only PKI smart card whose driver is integrated on each Windows since Windows 7 SP1 and which can be used read and write. No Windows driver installation is required and this card can be used instantly.

My Smart Logon (link below) is providing free of charge a applet to transform a java card into a GIDS smart card and its integration in OpenSC for other operating systems (Linux, MacOSX, …).
usage:
The installation should be simple without any required information. All necessary links are provided below. There are many host applications and many tools to work with, but the actual usage is pretty difficult. Fortunately, if you look enough there are plenty websites that offer solutions. We list some of them.

Card Initialization

To easy setup the applet, download GIDS Initialization tool. Run in only once! If you are advanced user and prefer to do things yourself, follow https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/wiki/Quick-Start-with-OpenSC tutorial how to initialize the card using OpenSC (command line only).

Applet usage

Download OpenSC tool (command line only) for your operating system to further setup and manage your applet (for example load cerificates). For more info on OpenSC, read the WIKI on the repository page.

There are many tools for the GIDS applet to work with, CertUtil is a great tool to manage certificates. We also mention this tool to warn you - for windows, disable the CertUtil ability to use the Internet (more on https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/forums/t/674836/locking-down-certutil/)

Also, we recommend to have a look on javacardos.com for dealing with issues (for example https://www.javacardos.com/javacardforum/viewtopic.php?t=1667)

name: YubicoYubiKeyOath
title: YubiKey Oath
author: Yubico
description: This project implement the HOTP/TOTP card functionality used on the YubiKey NEO device that is sold by Yubico. Its primary use is to use the YubiKey NEO to generate OATH HOTP/TOTP one-time-passwords.
usage:
Installation does not require any information. You need android phone with NFC for the applet to use. Although this applet claims to work with either yubico authenticator for desktop or android, we were able to succesfully run the yubico on android only (for more info see https://github.com/Yubico/ykneo-oath/issues/20). Don't be confused; the android app will not recognize your card straight away. First, you have to ad a an account. Do not ad an account unless you know for which you want to enable 2FA first. More details on this in HOTP/TOTP section. The 'save action' will require you to use a card as the actual credentials are to be transfered onto applet. After that, the applet is initialized with the entries you provided and ready to perform HOTP or TOTP based on your account settings.

HOTP/TOTP

is a one-time-password generator protocol that relies on counter (HOTP) or a timestamp (TOTP). Counter is increased every time new password is generated, the timestamp includes a time limit the password is valid within (30/60s).
The one-time passwords are good for 2FA (two factor) authentication. More information on how to proceed can be found on the websites that support 2FA in the links below (linkedIn, for example: https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/531). For the host app account creation, you have to have your account existing - and add the two factor authentication feature to it by adding your account to android app that initializes the applet. After succesful setup, the authentication on the webpage will require you to generate and submit a one time key (that was created on the card).

name: philipWendlandIsoApplet
title: ISO Applet
author: Philip Wendland
description: The Java Card IsoApplet (e.g. for use with OpenSC). The Applet is capable of saving a PKCS#15 file structure and performing PKI related operations using the private key, such as signing or decrypting. Private keys can be generated directly on the smart card or imported from the host computer. The import of private keys is disabled in the default security configuration. The applet targets modern Smartcards with Java Card 2.2.2 or above.
usage:
No installation parameters are required. The aplet can be communicated with using OpenSC tool (command line). OpenSC provides various functionality for many various applets, only some of the commands will work. For example, in the description you can see PKCS#15. Then you need to use openSC tool for PKCS#15.

Checking installation

Send opensc-tool --name to see whether OpenSC recognizes the card. You should see 'Javacard with IsoApplet' written in the output.

Applet initialization

use pkcs15-init -C command and follow the instructions. More info in the personalisation link.

Applet details

Use pkcs15-tool --list-info to get details about the IsoApplet.

Upload your key onto card

Send pkcs15-init -S [your key file] --auth-id [your pin id]. The key should be in PEM or DER format. Your PIN id can be displayed using pkcs15-tool --list-pins - see the ID column.


See many useful tutorials in the links below.

name: CrocsHotpViaNdef
title: HOTP via NDEF
author: Crocs MUNI
description:
JavaCard HMAC-based One Time Password generator which delivers new code via URL tag of NDEF every time the card is put close to NFC-enabled phone.

As a result, phone will display prompt to visit URL with current OTP code. No installation of phone software is required. The server side needs to parse OTP code properly from URL request.
usage: No installation parameters are required. Full tutorials (including video) can be found on wiki in the link below. First, initialize the applet with data and secret and then simply use the card! No host for use required - android works with this applet natively. The process of initialization is pointless to secribe it here, follow the step-by-step guides on the wiki.

name: martijno-ronnywsJMRTD
title: JMRTD: Machine readable Travel Document
author: martijno, ronnyws
description: Free implementation of the MRTD (Machine Readable Travel Documents) standards as set by ICAO used in the ePassport. Consists of an API for card terminal software and a Java Card applet. More information on the host wiki.
usage:
Download the host application and install it. If you have 64bit java and the installer thinks you don't have java, you need to download 32bit java version.

Install the applet onto card. No parameters are required. If the installation fails due to technology support issues, we recommedn to install the no-EAC applet instead.

Use the host application to manage passports, and eventually upload them onto card (open passport in edit mode, select Tools -> Upload Passport).

The uploaded passport should be readable from any ePassport compatible reader.

name: martijno-ronnyws-walterschellJMRTDnoEAC
title: JMRTD-no-EAC: Machine readable Travel Document without EAC
author: martijno, ronnyws
description: Free implementation of the MRTD (Machine Readable Travel Documents) standards without Extended Access Control (EAC) as set by ICAO used in the ePassport. Consists of an API for card terminal software and a Java Card applet. More information on the host wiki.
usage:
Download the host application and install it. If you have 64bit java and the installer thinks you don't have java, you need to download 32bit java version.

Install the applet onto card. No parameters are required.

Use the host application to manage passports, and eventually upload them onto card (open passport in edit mode, select Tools -> Upload Passport)

.

name: ToporinSatoChipApplet
title: Satochip Applet
author: Toporin
description:
Open source javacard applet implementing a Bitcoin hardware wallet with full BIP32 support. SatoChip stands for Secure Anonymous Trustless and Open Chip. It is a javacard applet that can be used as a secure hardware wallet running for example on a Yubikey Neo. The SatoChip has full BIP32 supports.
Using SatoChip, an initial BIP32 seed is imported in the javacard and private keys are derived as requested by an external application. Private keys are never exported outside of the secure chip. To improve performances, the result of key derivation is cached in secure memory for future requests so that a specific derivation path is only computed once.
The Satochip also supports the import of regular (non-BIP32 keys) such as vanity keys. Here again, private keys cannot be exported outside of the secure chip. Up to 16 regular keys can be imported on the chip. In any case, the private keys can be used to sign transactions and Bitcoin messages, if sufficient credentials are provided.
Access to private keys (creation, derivation and signature) is enforced through the use of PIN code.
The Satochip wallet is currently in Beta, use with caution! In this phase, it is strongly recommended to use the software on the Bitcoin testnet only. This software is provided 'as-is', without any express or implied warranty. In no event will the authors be held liable for any damages arising from the use of this software.
usage:
No installation parameters are required. Once installed, install and run Electrum-satochip host app from the link below. Create new standard wallet and select hardware wallet. You will be asked to setup your PIN for the applet. Continue with the dialog window, if the app does not respond wait a while - it talks to the smart card. Once done, you can start using your personal bitcoin wallet!
Use with care: the bitcoins are not accessible if you accidentaly erase the applet or destroy/lose your card!
The Electrum-Satochip wallet is currently in Beta, so use with caution! In this phase, it is recommended to use the software on the Bitcoin testnet only (electrum.exe -v --testnet). This software is provided 'as-is', without any express or implied warranty. In no event will the authors be held liable for any damages arising from the use of this software.

name: status-imStatusKeycard
title: Keycard
author: Status
description:
Keycard is a an implementation of a BIP-32 HD wallet running on Javacard 3.0.4+ (see implementation notes).
It supports among others

  • key generation, derivation and signing
  • exporting keys defined in the context of EIP-1581 https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1581
  • setting up a NFC NDEF tag

Communication with the Keycard happens through a simple APDU interface, together with a Secure Channel guaranteeing confidentiality, authentication and integrity of all commands. It supports both NFC and ISO7816 physical interfaces, meaning that it is compatible with any Android phone equipped with NFC, and all USB Smartcard readers.
The most obvious case for integration of Keycard is crypto wallets (ETH, BTC, etc), however it can be used in other systems where a BIP-32 key tree is used and/or you perform authentication/identification.


This software contains two applets (unlike official release, we decided to remove 'Cash applet' due to low use case'). The first applet is a KeyCard - wallet, the second applet is NDEF tag. More on NDEF can be found in NDEF applets section - the use case is the same.
usage:
The installation should be simple. You may change the applet AIDs as desribed below. However, the store fills default AIDs that are correct in most cases. Change the values only if you know you have to.

KeyCard applet (A000000804000101)

There can be multiple instances of this applet installed. Append to the applet AID the number of an instance you install. Valid nubers are 0x00 - 0xff (255), For first installation add 0x01 as 'first instance':A00000080400010101.

NDEF applet (A000000804000102)

This applet AID has to conform to it's own package. However, the actual installation has to be done with different AID as NDEF applets are supposed to have certain AID for communication. The correct AID for NDEF applet is D2760000850101.

Keycard Applet usage

After the installation, download the latest release of host application from its repository in the links below. The app can communicate with the applet; it can also install it - but this can be done in this store as well (it will install all the applets and won't let you choose unlike JCAppStore). Nevertheless, the app is still needed for further applet initialization and usage.

Initialize applet

in command line, either navigate to the folder where you've downloaded the host app executable, or make sure it is in a folder contained in your PATH environment variable (windows - unlikely in a PATH, either add it manually or go to the installation folder, unix - likely in /usr/bin) and run following command: keycard init -l debug. More info can be found in the app repo readme file.

Harware wallet host app

Once initialized, download any app that supports hardware wallets - smart cards. WallETH is an android ethereum wallet that supports a smart card pairing - simply select 'NFC smart card' once app starts, then 'add initialized wallet' as we initialized the walled just before. Then, provide PIN and pairing code you've received from keycard client app and tap the card to your phone.

NDEF tag usage

NDEF tokens are compatible with any android device equipped with NFC. Just download any NDEF tag application from Google Play to use. Apple phones should work similarly.

name: JavaCardOSKeepasNFC
title: Keepas NFC
author: JavaCardOS
description: KeepassNFC is an applet on javacard platform that can protect the secret key of your KeePass database. It is based on the project smartcard_crypto_applet and can be run on javacard platform with JCRE version 2.2.x or above. KeePass is a famous software about password management.
usage:
Install the applet - no installation parameters required. Once installed, you can use an android app to upload your keepass credentials onto card. The link to the app along with detailed tutorial can be found in the web links section below.

Note: In the tutorial, you can skip almost the whole "pyApduTool" section as the store do this for you automatically. Only thing you have to do yourself is to send custom APDU command to the applet once installed - go to your card and select the KeepasNFC applet. Click 'send custom command' and pass command B075000000 to tell it to generate new keypair. Now, the applet has generated the keypair (assuming the card master key is default 4041..4F, e.g. we didn't have to provide it when using gp).


Caveat: This applet is not considered to be ultimately secure (for common usage will suffice though): http://javacardos.com/javacardforum/viewtopic.php?t=998#p3043
